body:
Comment 9: 
I do not speak Japanese or Chinese. I took that word from the title of Rob
and Ken's paper http://plan9.bell-labs.com/sys/doc/utf.html, where it is
part of the larger phrase $B$3$s$K$A$O(B $B@$3&(B, which I believe to be Japanese.
From
some research it appears that $B@$3&(B means world in both Chinese and Japanese,
while $B$3$s$K$A$O(B is unambiguously Japanese. By using only part of the phrase I
introduced the ambiguity.

http://www.google.com/search?q=chinese+word+for+world
http://www.google.com/search?q=japanese+word+for+world

So I think the video is correct as written. If I were recording it again I
would say "Chinese or Japanese" or else change the example. But I don't
believe I have the original screencast source file anymore.

I apologize for any offense.
